required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: FiO2 and Outcomes After Cardiac Surgery With Cardiopulmonary Bypass
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Intraoperative Oxygen Tension on Patient Outcomes After Cardiac Surgery With Cardiopulmonary Bypass: a Pilot Study

brief_summary.textblock: Conventionally, a relatively high level of fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) has been used for secure a margin of safety in patients undergoing cardiac surgery using cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). Since the potential adverse effects of hyperoxemia (via reactive oxygen species, vasocontriction, perfusion heterogeneity, myocardiac injury, etc.), various studies on this topic has been performed. However, the results are conflicting and inconsistent, and the consensus about whether the use of additional oxygen supply in cardiac surgery using CPB has not been reached among practitioners yet.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Due to COVID-19 pandemic, it was no possible to recruit patients for this study.

primary_outcome.time_frame: From the beginning of surgery until the hospital discharge after surgery through study completion, an expected average of two weeks
primary_outcome.description: length of hospital stay after cardiac surgery using cardiopulmonary bypass

clinical_study.condition: Patients Undergoing Cardiac Surgery Using Cardiopulmonary Bypass

intervention.description: A fraction of inspired oxygen level during cardiac surgery using cardiopulmonary bypass will be set differently: 0.5 versus 1.0.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All patients scheduled for cardiac surgery using cardiopulmonary bypass
Exclusion Criteria:
- Planned implementation of deep hypothermic circulatory arrest
- Preoperative respiratory support with the fraction of inspired oxygen of 0.5 and more.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Professor of Anesthesiology and Pain Medicine
